title: ISic000829. I.Sicily inscription 000829
body:
Facsimile Images

1DUMESSETSACERDOSSYRIAEDEAE
2TIBERIUSTIBERIIF
3PONTIFEXFILDAPSILI
4AMPHILOBIVEROPAEADIAQUIFUITTHEODORIQUIFUIT
5MORRECINIQUIIUSTAFECERE
6PRAESIDESSYRIAEDEAESINGULISANNIS
7PPLONUSPFILIUS
8MPOMPONIUSDI[---]
9LLUCINIUS[---]
10LOCTAVIUSL[---]
11TPHAECIUS[---]
12ATTALE[---]
13EUTICH[---]

Apparatus criticus

Text after IG with slight changes

translation

commentary

The text is only recorded by Octavius Caietanus (1566-1620) in his 'Isagoge ad historiam sacram siculam' (published posthumously in 1707), where he simply describes it as a 'tabella mamorea Syracusis reperta graeco idiomate', which he renders in Latin. 'Amphilobi' clearly refers to an 'amphipolos'. It clearly bears close similarity to the inscriptions for Anna and the Paides from Buscemi (cf. ISic002997 or 002999), and given that and the Latin names, is probably of the early first century CE.

bibliography

  • Caietanus 1707 19-20 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002774
  • 14.0009 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001072
  • 3.5372 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001252
  • Tusa 1963 189 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001540
  • Wilson 1990 300 with n.102 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001509
  • Sfameni Gasparro 1973 162-164 no.358 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001586
